title: Bees make decisions better and faster than we do, for the things that matter to them
summary: A study led by Professor Andrew Barron from Macquarie University and Dr HaDi MaBouDi, Neville Dearden, and Professor James Marshall from the University of Sheffield has provided insights into the decision-making process of bees. The researchers trained bees to recognize different colored flower disks and observed their decision-making process. They found that bees make decisions quickly when they are confident about finding food, but take more time when they are unsure. The team then built a computer model based on the bees' decision-making process, which resembled the physical layout of a bee brain. The study highlights the potential for using insect brains to design better robots and improve our understanding of how our own brains evolved.
